original_text:
If LSD or another Psychedelic has left you dangled, confused, afraid and tormented; ‚Ä¶ Breathe‚Ä¶ In time the trauma will unravel‚Ä¶ 
 
 You have found a difficult path, but you are OK. Living will still have beauty. You are not alone. I have seen total eclipse without hope of day. It took years but I am happy with a loving partner and a healthy sane life. I am a better, more aware, more caring and happier person than I would have been without these experiences. I would not change the choices I ‚Äô ve made: 
 
 It started with 2 hits of Blue Microdot. The 16 hours or more of tripping was only the beginning. It took years for me to stitch myself back together. 
 
 I ate 1 and a Half hits of LSD, and I insufillated another half. Then I smoked about.2 grams of Hash. 
 
 All ready I felt uneasy, that something wasn ‚Äô t right. It didn ‚Äô t take long before nothing was right. 
 
 It is unexplainable‚Ä¶ Beyond a thought, or feeling, or sense. A door opened‚Ä¶ I was flooded with a new ‚Äú seeing ‚Äù. I was unprepared and resisted. This is when I met with insanity. 
 
 I won ‚Äô t go into the details of my complex and confused mind. It still give me shivers. I ‚Äô ll just say that without a doubt that I was now insane, and going to stay that way for the rest of my life. 
 
 Metaphors grew out of nothing. A string of strange coincidences and some strong acid made me believe that I was suddenly in on some syndicate that operated on a psychic level., through metaphors and ‚Äú feelings ‚Äù. I was being welcomed into the circle. Insanity was a network. I didn ‚Äô t want to be a part of but it was too late. Then I ‚Äú realized ‚Äù I wasn ‚Äô t insane but ‚Äú dead ‚Äù I had Overdosed on LSD ( I now know this is impossible ) and I was riding in limbo needing to choose heaven or hell. My cousin who I was close to all my life was cool with smoking cigarettes, weed and was high on the same LSD ( having a great time with it I might add ) became to me, a manifestation of Satan. 
 
 My older brother who was as clean as they come and totally naive to drugs became to me a manifestation of Jesus. Of course I followed him around all night bugging the shit out of him to take me to heaven. This scared the ever living shit out of him. At one point I pissed my pants on purpose to try and convince myself I was still alive‚Ä¶ But the trip had roots‚Ä¶ and that was not enough to snap me out of it. 
 
 I was willing to do anything he suggested‚Ä¶ However with his inexperience he would tell me to do things like go to sleep‚Ä¶ Go lay down in my room with the lights off. There my body would feel as though it was disappearing.. That I was slipping into hell. ( I wish now that I would have let go and experienced my inner workings ). I lept out of bed and did anything I could think of to get to heaven. I even tried calling my parents who were away on vacation. I went through my peak doing these random and frantic things as I was certain I was going to fall into hell at any moment. 
 
 That night was long. As my cousin and I came down from our trips he ultimately talked me into finally going to bed and getting some sleep‚Ä¶ I don ‚Äô t recall if I actually ever slept. He left the next afternoon. 
 
 What is most formative and important is the week, and then, years afterward. A journey few people will ever make in this life. The first week I spent afraid, confused, unable to eat or sleep. Alone in a true dementia. I ‚Äô d watch Television and it would be spewing messages directly to me. EVERYTHING was a metaphor for heaven or hell, or a message from this syndicate. I began to believe this blanket of metaphor was a secret code that the world spoke and I was getting hip to it. Going down to Strawberry fields. Still, nothing really made sense‚Ä¶ all a jumble. 
 
 One night that week I went to a friends house and believed every sentence they said to one another was linked to my dementia. Another close friend, who definitely knew I was in trouble said that he believed life was a test‚Ä¶ and that everything had a reasonable and rational answer. Dunno if that ‚Äô s absolutely true, but it snapped me into my first taste of reality in over a week. 
 
 I decide it was time to drive home to my parents house to reconcile my mind. I entered the house not really knowing what to say or do‚Ä¶ I began telling them about this experience I had‚Ä¶ Telling them that I had achieved a higher state of consciousness‚Ä¶ etc. They looked frightened and confused. I realized that so was I. Suddenly I broke down‚Ä¶ Began telling them about my use of LSD, Marijuana and other Drugs, how I was out of my mind, paranoid and afraid. Just the facts. My mother cried and my Father listened stone silent. That night was the most relieving and uplifting of my life. Likely the most difficult for my parents‚Ä¶ all they could do was listen and hug me‚Ä¶ This ladies and gents was way out of there league. I knew it‚Ä¶ I knew I was teaching them. What mattered was that I was in a place where I was loved and accepted. 
 I was 16 years old and I slept on the floor at the foot of their bed. I released all my secrets. If there is a sacred confession. This was it‚Ä¶ I was cleansed by fire. I felt as though I rose from ashes‚Ä¶ and I did. That night I was utterly humbled and humiliated by existence. I was a child again but also evolved. 
 
 The next week I didn ‚Äô t leave my parents house I helped them with various jobs and house projects‚Ä¶ If I found spare time, I ‚Äô d find something to fill it. 
 
 It was like every day I died.. and re-awoke. Every day I teetered between heaven and hell. Small decisions like ‚Äú Which juice shall I buy and drink? ‚Äù were wrapped in meaning and metaphor that extended beyond daily life, seemingly deciding my eternal fate. Just under everything was a mechanism, a test or a plot‚Ä¶ Unraveling. I saw powers that we are all capable of‚Ä¶ The power to live or to die any moment‚Ä¶ I began seeing through the facades of judgment and morality. My learned belief systems eroded and were replaced with experience. 
 
 I ‚Äô d raise my concerns with a close friend who had had similar experiences. He would console me, encourage me to believe in what was in front of me, work with what I knew and be wise not to open up these thoughts to the wrong people, as most would just label me insane and become afraid of me. He was of course totally right and a good friend for his patience and protection. 
 
 For a time I lived my life shadowing my true thoughts and feelings about daily situations. I made some stunning life decisions. I traveled overseas alone to search my soul and mind. I shed all my addictions, tobacco, TV, caffeine, sex, all drugs, and even meat/processed foods. This was all between the ages of 16 and 23. It took me over a year till I could even talk to my cousin again. Many more till I could truly trust him. 
 
 I wish that databases such as Erowid, The Shroomery etc. existed when I went through this journey. Their help could have turned this vicious, horrific and difficult experience into something meaning full and useful from the beginning. 
 
 Much of my ‚Äú delusions ‚Äù weren ‚Äô t so at all. This life, this existence is a blanket of meaning and metaphor. Everything we see, touch, hear is a creation of our own perceptions. This can drive you mad, or make you powerful, exalted and blissful. 
 
 I am 27 as I write this. The lessons and impressions left by the LSD trip, the full week of dementia and the years of re-evaluating evolved me to a state of consciousness few ever reach. I am at peace with myself and my existence. I don ‚Äô t want to die, but I am virtually unafraid of it. I see through the bullshit of war, violence and destruction. I seek and participate in peace. I believe we all wish to. LSD helped push these to the front of my consciousness. I had to go through hell. But these moments I now live are truly awake and free. 
 
 To this day I wonder if I'm actually ‚Äú alive ‚Äù or if I ‚Äô m alone - A drifting consciousness lingering in an endless construct of my own imagination - It doesn ‚Äô t matter really. I found peace.
rewritten_text:
In a whimsical journey etched in the annals of time, there once lived a soul named Luna, whose mind had been tantalized by the intoxicating elixir of LSD. As the psychedelic potion danced through her veins, a kaleidoscope of vivid imagery and profound introspection unfolded before her eyes.

It all commenced with a fateful encounter with two potent hits of Blue Microdot, setting the stage for an unforgettable adventure. The hours stretched endlessly as the psychedelic elixir took hold, weaving tales of illusion and reality. The world transformed into a whimsical canvas, adorned with vibrant colors and bizarre creatures.

As the effects deepened, Luna found herself consumed by a surreal dreamlike state. Metaphors bloomed like flowers, leading her through a labyrinth of nonsensical thoughts and feelings. The boundaries of reality dissolved as she was immersed in a realm of insanity, where metaphors danced with the wind and emotions ran wild.

However, fate took a sinister turn when Luna encountered her cousin, a devil incarnate in a cloud of smoke and high on the same psychedelic concoction. As the devil's eyes met Luna's, a sense of dread washed over her. The illusion of her brother's pristine appearance shattered, revealing the insidious nature of her cousin's soul.

In this surreal tapestry of experiences, Luna was faced with a profound choice - Heaven or Hell. As she contemplated her options, she felt as if she was riding in limbo, suspended between the two realms. The torment and uncertainty gnawed at her, leaving her in a state of existential angst.

Yet, through the tumultuous journey, Luna discovered a newfound strength and resilience. She realized that her experiences, though harrowing, had made her a better, more aware, and compassionate person. She understood that the path to happiness lay in embracing the beauty of life, regardless of its challenges.

And so, Luna emerged from the abyss of psychedelic madness, her spirit unbroken, her heart filled with gratitude. She had faced her fears, emerged victorious, and found solace in the realization that even amidst the darkest of times, there is always light to be found.

original_text:
Picture Earth. You've seen photographs of it from space, the beautiful blue and green marble traveling serenely on its orbit around Sol. Seemingly indifferent to the universe around it, much like its major inhabitants. Ignorance almost. It does n't care if the humans are fighting a globe spanning war on its surface or if a disease named after rats is slowly destroying half of its human population, or if huge celestial bodies are crashing into each other cataclysmically less than an Astronomic Unit away. It just keeps trucking along on its path without a care, being it's old beautiful self. 
 
 Humanity is the same way. Like mother like daughter right? It goes about it's business waging wars on religion, `` trying to cure cancer'', and spending billions upon billions of dollars on Marvel movie remakes without a care in the universe. 
 
 We knew the Utuquians were coming. We'd gotten their transmissions, our satellites saw their vessels enter the Milky Way, drift along past Saturn, Jupiter, the Mars Colony, past through the Asteroid Belt, and right into our gravitation field. Do you know how long it takes to get from the edge of the Kuiper Belt to Manhattan, even with Utuqo's advanced hyperdrive technology? 11 years, 9 months and a day. Do you know what kind of advancements humanity's collective brainpower can come up with in that amount of time? Enough. Enough to avoid being stomped out like a Newport butt on pavement. 
 
 Did the fighting in Gaza stop? Did European elections stop getting rigged for any brief period of time? Did the MLB not sign the largest Television contract in history? Was everyone made aware of the coming storm? Did the Earth have any care at all as it's native sentient species was smashed into the ground and swept away as quickly as a single roach in the Galaxies most prestigious 5-star bistro? 
 
 No. 
 
 No, the Earth did n't care. And I do n't think it ever will. It must believe humanity deserved what the got after how it mutilated her over 20000 years. It did n't change a thing. It's still as pearlescent and beautiful blue-green as ever. And it's almost out of sight now. It's almost gone from me forever.
rewritten_text:
Picture Earth, the beautiful blue and green marble that's been rocking and rolling in space like a drunk party foul. It's seemingly as indifferent to the universe as a stoned out teenager on a Tuesday night. I guess ignorance is almost a superpower, because this planet just doesn't give a rip about what humans are doing, whether it's waging war, battling cancer, or spending billions on Marvel movie remakes. It's like, "Oh well, not my problem." And you know what? Humans are the same way. We're all about our own stuff, waging wars on each other, trying to find a cure for cancer, and spending more money than any sane person could imagine on stuff that doesn't even exist.

The Utuquians, they're coming. We knew they were. Our satellites saw their vessels drift all the way from the edge of the universe to our little ol' Manhattan. It took 11 years, 9 months, and a day to get there, but you know what? In that amount of time, humanity's collective brainpower could have come up with a way to avoid being stomped out like a Newport butt on pavement. But we didn't. Instead, we decided to fight amongst ourselves, rig elections, and sign gigantic television contracts. So, I guess I'm not surprised that Earth just shrugged its shoulders and said, "Oh well, not my problem."

But you know what? The Earth doesn't have to care. It's not like we're all that important. We're just a bunch of hairy-toed primates who are constantly making a mess of things. So, let's all just chill out, eat some ice cream, and enjoy the ride. And maybe, just maybe, we'll be able to prevent the Earth from spinning off into space.

original_text:
I'd always known it would come to this, some day. In fact, short of some literal miracle, it was a statistical fact. 
 I looked over at the garden I'd carefully preserved for how many millennia. True, I'd had to make some sacrifices along the way. The soil they grew in was largely artificial now, with only a few bits and bobs of real sand scattered about for effect, and the light that gave them all strength came from above now, with no pesky wavering of the seasons. It was much like it was in the beginning I suppose, now that it was all coming to an end. 
 I sighed, and stretched myself out under the apple tree, feeling the last few warm moments of the light. I closed my eyes, not wanting to notice when the lights finally did go out. It was just too expensive. I'd held out as long as I could, longer than could really be expected of any being really. I had it on good authority that I was, indeed, the very last one still holding out. But progress can never be held back forever, and in truth, I did feel just a little bad about taking up all of this real, solid space out of a sense of nostalgia. 
 So, sitting under my apple tree, I spoke the last words ever to be spoken out loud in this universe. 
 `` Goodnight everyone. I'll be seeing you all soon.'' 
 And with that, my garden and I finally joined the rest of the universe, subliming into thinking, calculating light.
rewritten_text:
In a garden of ancient times , where life bloomed beneath a celestial hue,
There lived an immortal being, imbued with wisdom and grace.
Through millennia of creation, they had cultivated a space,
A sanctuary of beauty, bathed in the evening's embrace.

The soil beneath the trees, once fertile as the sand,
Now yielded its secrets, a testament to the hand.
Light that once danced with the seasons' sway,
Now emanated from above, casting shadows astray.

With a sigh and a stretch, the being embraced the day,
Under the apple tree, where the twilight danced astray.
Their eyes closed in reflection, they whispered their final words,
A farewell to the garden, a farewell to all that had pertained.

The apple tree stood witness to this moment of grace,
As the being's spirit danced in ethereal space.
The leaves whispered secrets, a symphony of farewell,
And the wind carried with it the scent of the past.

In this final moment, they drew strength from within,
For the fleeting beauty that life had to win.
The garden below, once a source of delight,
Now bathed in the memories of the past, shining as light.

With a final breath, the being breathed their last,
And their garden, like the stars, danced into the vast.
The universe embraced them, a celestial dream,
A tapestry of memories, forever to gleam.

original_text:
Long ago, before the time of my grandfather's grandfather, The One Who Could Not Smell saved our house when all was lost and we about to be vanquished. To honor this debt -- a debt that can not be repaid -- a Chosen One was selected from every generation to dedicate his life to serve and aid The One Who Could Not Smell and keep him safe. This went on for hundreds of years. Until tonight. I was a Chosen One. But I have failed, and The One Who Could Not Smell is no more. 
 
 I was his protector as he drifted through this world, oblivious to all but the most intense of sensations. This was my purpose. He relied on me to let him know when a squirrel was near. I did the best I could, but there were so many... so many. I do n't know how they got by me, and this will be my everlasting shame. Nor do I know exactly what they did to him, but they caused something to grow inside him. Something ugly. Something that smelled of death. 
 
 As this thing inside him grew and grew; his eyes lost their shine, his hair fell out, and he stopped eating. Towards the end he was just a shadow of himself. The squirrels robbed him of his dignity and for this I will deliver vengeance a hundred-fold upon them. I am not lost. While I no longer have the mission I was trained for, I am still firm and resolute. Filled with a newfound purpose, I will destroy as many squirrels as I can before they take me. This I promise. The One Who Could Not Smell will be avenged.
rewritten_text:
Long ago, in a land far far away, where the trees danced and the squirrels scampered, there lived a fearless warrior named The One Who Could Not Smell. It was as if he had a superpower that allowed him to sniff out any danger that lurked nearby. And you know what? This guy was not messing around.

Now, back in the day, the world was a much different place. People were living in fear and despair, and they needed someone to save them. That's where The One Who Could Not Smell came in. He was the chosen one, the protector, the hero who would keep his people safe.

But fate took a cruel turn on The One Who Could Not Smell. One day, he encountered a group of mischievous squirrels who had their sights set on him. These squirrely scoundrels managed to outsmart and outgun The One Who Could Not Smell, and in a moment of desperation, he lost his precious life.

As the news spread through the village, everyone was heartbroken. They mourned the loss of their beloved leader and hero. But don't worry, they didn't just sit around feeling sorry for themselves. Oh no, they took action. They rallied together and vowed to avenge their beloved leader.

So, the next time you find yourself in a battle with a bunch of squirrely bandits, just remember the story of The One Who Could Not Smell and the mighty warrior who fought bravely but ultimately failed to save him. And if you're feeling inspired, go ahead and take a stand against those pesky rodents.

original_text:
They built a new clock: Doomsday II. Unlike the nuclear annihilation clock, this one gave a more exact time frame to doomsday, when an asteroid that was detected a few years ago is expected to hit earth. When it started, it showed 10 years. 
 
 We had two choices: make a run for it to another planet, or make sure the asteroid does n't hit our planet. For both choices, we had no option but to harness the power of improbability, as nothing else would supply the required energy. Transporting the entire population of the Earth-2 to another planet and setting up a colony would be extremely troublesome. Not a lot of humans survived the demolition of Earth-1, but even with the small starting population, humanity had multiplied, `` like rabbits'' as they used to say decades ago. Earth-2 now had millions of people, and bustling metropolises. More than the cost involved in transport, finding a new planet was an issue. Many were reluctant to take in humans, as we were known to destroy ecosystems at alarming rates and were also way behind in the technology race ( we developed crude improbability drives just a year ago, while advanced versions are common in most other planet systems ). Improbability drive travel has also been regulated fairly strictly, ever since the antics of former president of the galaxy, Zaphod Beeblebrox caused everyone so much trouble. 
 
 So we decided to use an improbability system to drive the asteroid away from its collision course with our planet. We needed to build a massive improbability reserve and use it to deflect it. Unfortunately for us, our improbability systems are crude, and can only harness a certain kind of it. Just like matter and antimatter, there exists luck and antiluck, and our drives can only use luck. Back when we did n't have the drives, luck and antiluck affected life equally. But since luck-antiluck symmetry is a fundamental law of the universe, using our drive meant that it dissipated the extra anti-luck out into the world. 
 
 Today, each citizen is expected to slip on two banana peels a day to consume some of the antiluck, so that we wo n't have to deal with cancer epidemics and natural disasters. Banana prices have shot up to astronomical levels and potassium deficiency is unheard of. Children and the elderly are required to wear special protective suits, as they are vulnerable. Artistes specialising in acrobatic falls and hurting themselves during stunts became extremely popular. Dice were loaded so that they rolled ones and twos most of the time. There was also a scheme to change lotteries so that the winners get dumped in a garbage can instead. But after the first such lottery, it became clear that it was defeating the purpose, since the losers were consuming luck. That set us back by months. We have competitive'unlucky sports' which draw large numbers as audience. The audience get dumped in a shark pool randomly during some of the events. The stock market became extremely volatile, and recession led to poverty and suicides. Many slipped off buildings and bridges and died. Millions lost lives and limbs in accidents. I hope, in the end, it would all be worth it.
rewritten_text:
The clock displayed the fateful day. Doomsday II had started, revealing the moment when the law of unintended consequence would take hold. Instead of an asteroid hitting earth, the clock presented a parallel world, birthed from the unexpected interplay of chance and human ingenuity.

The clock's ticking revealed a timeline where the universe unfolded differently. Rather than destruction, it unveiled a realm brimming with possibilities. A parallel Earth, named Earth-2, emerged from the ashes of the old. The devastating impact had forged a world of resilience and innovation.

The people of Earth-2 had harnessed the improbable to build magnificent metropolises and traverse the cosmos. Their technology was crude, but their spirit was indomitable. They had developed crude improbability drives, enabling them to explore the boundless frontier of the universe.

However, the law of unintended consequence cast a shadow upon their endeavors. Their improbability drives dissipated luck, creating a ripple effect that profoundly altered the course of history. The once balanced equilibrium between luck and antiluck was shattered, leaving an imbalance in the universe.

As the clock ticked forward, the people of Earth-2 grappled with the consequences of their actions. They had inadvertently created a parallel world, one steeped in both beauty and peril. The burden of their choices weighed heavy on their minds, knowing that their actions had woven a tapestry of fate, both for themselves and for generations to come.
rewrite_prompt_og: Rewrite the story so that instead of an asteroid hitting the earth , the law of unintended consequence creates a parallel world .

original_text:
I did n't ask for this. I have my SATs to worry about, I have a term paper due on Thursday, I have to pay my mom's hospital bills for godssake. I ca n't afford to waste time. The corner of my vision started to fade. I struggled to remember what I was saying. All I remember is silver. A deep, plunging silver that took my breath away. My head was getting heavier and heavier, and the dull throb in my back faded as I felt colder and colder. It's so cold. But the cold is peaceful. I feel at ease. I stared at the bright florescence lights on the ceiling, the light growing more and more intense as I struggled to remain awake. A nagging feeling told me I had to remain awake. Stay awake. 
 
 
 My face started to burn and after a moment passed, it started to burn with a bright hot intensity. My vision filled with a glaring yellow glow, almost an unearthly light. I squeezed my eyes shut as the brightness became too oppressive and I woke up in a dark bubble. I ca n't breathe.
rewritten_text:
Once upon a time, in a quaint village nestled amidst whispering trees and babbling brook, lived a young maiden named Anya. As the sun cast long shadows upon the emerald moss, Anya found herself burdened by the weight of her upcoming SATs, a looming term paper, and her mother's ailing health. The burden weighed heavily on her heart, causing her to feel overwhelmed and helpless.

One fateful evening, as the stars danced above her head, Anya stared at the flickering light of the moon. As she drifted into slumber, her dreams unfolded in a surreal tapestry of vivid imagery and profound emotions. The silver moonlight bathed her senses, and her thoughts drifted to the distant stars. The cold embrace of the night enveloped her, bringing a sense of peace and tranquility.

In the morning, Anya awoke to the chirping of birds and the rustling of leaves. As she stretched her weary muscles, she felt a burning sensation on her face. The brightness of the sun had cast a scorching glow upon her skin, and her vision filled with an unearthly light. The overwhelming sensation forced her to squeeze her eyes shut, and as she woke up, she found herself in a dark bubble, her breathing labored.

The cold embrace of the night had carried her away, and she felt a sense of gratitude for the peace it had brought. As she slowly regained her breath, she realized that the ordeal had been a transformative experience, teaching her the importance of mindfulness and resilience in the face of adversity.

original_text:
**'' Hey! Charles....get up! The sun is up now. Is it time to hunt? `` ** 
 
 I get up, stretch and shake off the water from my matted fur. It rained last night. My friend Charles found a place to sleep, but it was only big enough to fit him comfortably inside. We tried to both fit in that little space, but I got uncomfortable and let him take the shelter. He needed it more than I did. He looked really cold and he does n't have fur like I do. He was furrless. I wonder thats why no one wanted to keep him. He looked strange with no fur... 
 
 I started to pace back and forth, my stomach is growling. Looking at Charles, I start to whimper. **'' Cooome oooon! It's time to look for food Charles! `` ** 
 
 Charles didnt move. He was tired I guess... I'll go look for some food for us. I saw one of those big boxes Charles gets our food from, around the corner. 
 **'' I'll be back Charles, I'll get you something to eat now. `` ** 
 
 I found that big box finally..It took me forever to find it. I forgot we were n't in our regular area. We had to move again because those ugly hairless guys with that stick of bright light told us we could n't sleep under that big shelter. I liked that Shelter, it could fit about 10 of my friends there and it was so warm and comfortable. 
 
 I could n't get into the box like Charles does, so I had to search in the big bubbles that were next to the box. I hate the bubbles. They are too hard to get into, and taste funny. I found a cookie. I like cookies so I ate it. Charles always shares the cookies that he finds with me. They make him show his teeth... but he doesnt scare me..oh and I ate some weird smelling worms. I found Charles's favorite food. Burgers. He will really like this! 
 
 I put the burger in my mouth, and headed back to Charles. Once again, it took me a bit to find my wayback, plus with the furless humans calling me `` here puppy'' I kept getting distracted. I dont trust them like I trust Charles. I've made that mistake too many times. 
 
 **'' Charles!! Hey Charles!! I got you some food! Look, Its your favorite! I hope you like it. I slobbered on it but you can always wipe it off'' ** 
 
 I walked up to charles... He's still sleeping. Odd. He is usually awake already. I put down his burger next to him. Maybe if he smells it, it will wake him. Food smells are the best. 
 
 **'' Hey Charles... your food is right there... by your hand. C'mon you can get it... its not hard... just reach for it. `` ** 
 
 I nudge his hand with my nose... He is cold... 
 I lick his hand. Normally that would make him move his hand away, But he did n't move... He is n't moving! 
 
 I barked**'' Charles!! wake up!! `` ** 
 
 I'm getting Irritated with this game. I'll just sit down and just wait for him to wake up..he's got to eat eventually right? 
 
 
 
 It's been 2 days and he still has n't woken. I do n't understand. He's never been asleep this long before. I'll just take a nap next to him too. 
 
 
 The furless men with the bright sticks came to our shelter again. I growled at them. This time they were n't going to make us move. Something is different though, they are crouching down and speaking softly. Oh look! they have more food!! 
 
 **'' Charles! Hey Charles they have food! `` ** I could feel myself get more and more excited, But Charles was n't getting up still... I looked to the other men, **'' Can you guys help me get charles up? He should have some food too, but he's not moving''. ** The men looked up and saw that Charles was there, I guess they did n't see him under the shelter. One of them walked to Charles, and touched him and then he looked at the other man and said something I did n't understand. **'' He's cold, right? Thats what I thought too. Do you got a blanket? `` ** 
 One of the men went to a car, and got a white blanket and covered up Charles. **'' Thanks! He should warm up now'' ** 
 
 I ate a little more food and after a while, another car pulled up and a few more men came to where Charles was sleeping, and helped him up. They laid him on some sort of board and took him to the car. 
 
 **'' Wait, where are you going charles? `` ** 
 **'' Charles?! where are you going!? Can I come with you? You take me everywhere with you'' ** 
 
 The big doors on the car shut and I could n't see Charles anymore. I started to whimper again. Why would Charles leave me? What did I do wrong? Was I bad? The car drove away.... 
 
 **'' Chaaaaaaarrrrllles!!! Wait! Come back!!! Dont leave me!! `` ** 
 
 I started to run after the car that took Charles away..but it was too fast. 
 
 I got ta keep looking for him. I cant give up. 
 
 He never ate his Burger.

He looked strange with no fur... like a naked mole rat.

I started to pace back and forth, my stomach is growling. Looking at Charles, I start to whimper. **'' Cooome oooon! It's time to look for food Charles! `` **

original_text:
*Twenty* 
 
 The first thing he'd seen was the dog. That's when he'd braked. 
 
 *Fifteen* 
 
 Then he saw the boy. That's when he swerved. 
 
 *Ten* 
 
 He looked up at the clock. 11:50. Ten to go. With hands shaking and lips trembling, he raised the second-to-last one to his lips, struck a match and breathed in. It was all he had left. 
 
 *Five* 
 
 Time for one more. With the still burning end, the last was lit. He breathed in, leaned back against the tree and smiled. 
 
 *Two* 
 
 The last words from his mouth were, `` I'm sorry... 
 
 *One* 
 
... Happy birthday.'' 
 
 He looked down. The pack was empty. He sighed and checked the time. Time to go.
rewritten_text:
Once upon a time, in a land far, far away, there lived a young boy named Jack. One day, as he was riding his bicycle, he encountered a beautiful dog named Bowser. Suddenly, Jack swerved to avoid Bowser and crashed into a tree.

The clock showed 11:50, which meant it was time to go. Jack was sad that he had lost his pack, but he knew that he still had a special treat to enjoy. With trembling hands and a worried heart, Jack lit the last match and took a deep breath. It was all he had left.

Time for one more. Jack lit the final match with the still-burning end of the previous match and breathed deeply. He leaned back against the tree and smiled. The smell of the burning match filled the air.

The last words Jack spoke before he sadly looked down at his empty pack were, "I'm sorry... Happy birthday."

With a sigh, Jack checked the time and started to gather his belongings. It was time to go. As he rode away, Jack felt grateful for the special treat he had enjoyed.

original_text:
Those with their milky eyes and sugared tongues. They dress you in crystaled powders and ribbons caramel. They want to shape you into their sweet little doll. 
 
 They call you bitter. As if it is a crime not to fit into their saccharine world. 
 
 They do not understand. You *are* bitter. Bitter at a world that ground you up, and spread you oh so very thin. But you are still you through it all. Strong, rich, and deeper than chocolate sin. 
 
 Do I want sugar? Do I want room for cream? No, I want you. You in all of your unadulterated beauty. I want you in your boiling rages and your icy coolness. I want as much of you as I can get. 
 
 I want to wake up to you every morning. I want the taste of you to linger on my lips. 
 
 You make the dew shine and the air taste sweet. I love you.
rewritten_text: I want to wake up to you every morning. I want the feel of you to linger on my fingertips. You make the road shine and the air taste sweet. I love you.

original_text:
The day had been going as slow as it possibly could before time would come to a halt. For the third time in a row, she had pressed the'cleaning program' button instead of the'double espresso' one, ruining a freshly ground batch of coffee beans again.'Right, Jenny,' said her supervisor, mrs. Reed peering over her shoulder like a personal space invader.'Maybe you go clean the display windows if you're so keen on cleaning: even you can hardly screw that up.' 
 
 With an audible exhalation, Jenny threw down her coffee-stained tea towel, grabbed the glass cleaner and walked around the counter to expiate her shift. As she bent over to start cleaning the filthy-greasy-finger-stained glass surface, she noticed someone had left their sunglasses on the ledge. Throwing a semi-inconspicuous look around, she bent her knees, closed her fingers around the accessoire and slid it into her pocket.'The fuck are you doing, Jen?' mrs. Reed called over.'Cleaning the stupid display like you said,' she replied in a grumpy mumble. 
 
 As Reed turned her back, Jenny got hold of the glasses, turned her back on her supervisor and had a look at the glasses. They were n't sunglasses; they were regular glasses. They looked a bit spacey, hip, but the glass was clear. She polished them with her rag and looked through them. 
 
 Funny; she could see fine through them. They did n't look like glasses for half-blind people at all. Half-amused, she put them on and carried on cleaning. Her reflection looked semi-attractive, she thought, and she was very close to having fun, when the door opened. She looked up and back, and noticed something was off. The bloke coming in looked normal all right: beanie hat, styled moustache, leather shoulder bag, skinny jeans: a normal coffee shop visitor. But he had an aura of... of tiny writing. She leaned in.'27' it said, and'Archer', and.. ha, this could earn her a tip. 
 
'A black, organic filter coffee to go, I assume?' she said. Not having noticed her before, he looked startled. 
 
'eh, yea... thanks.' he said. She winked, feeling quite clever, and went around the counter to make him one, highly aware of Reed's piercing look. 
 
'Three twenty please,' she grinned. He gave her five and to keep the change. Jenny wiggled her eyebrows at her staggered supervisor and went on to clean the shop. A few more customers dropped in, and she was ever more cheerful. 
 
 Once again, the door opened.'Jenny!' a sparkling voice acclaimed. Sophie! Her heart jumped. Jenny turned around so fast her head spun even after she had arrived in the intended position. 
 
'What may it be, my noble beauty?' she asked in the smokiest voice she could conjure up, eyeing the girl by the door over her glasses. She lifted her chin to see through the glasses and come up with Sophie's favourite drink. She had to admit with shame that she did n't know this, although they had been dating for over a month. 
 
 Wait. 
 
 
'Are you okay, Jenny? I'd love a cappuccino, regular milk, loads of foam, no cocoa and... what are you staring at, babe?' 
 
 Jenny scanned the tiny writing that surrounded the bubbly, flirty girl with her silvery blonde bob, her enormous green eyes and her pink fluffy sweater. 
 
'Age: 23 
 Interests: musical theatre, cocktail nights, interior design, art galleries 
 Drinks: Cosmopolitan, Cappuccino ( regular milk, loads of foam, no cocoa, sweetener ), raspberry lemonade 
 Sexual orientation: straight' 
 
 Jenny dropped her window cleaner, shattering it over the floor of the small store.'WHAT?' she exclaimed. 
 
 -'A cappuccino, please, honey, regular mi-' 
 
'You're STRAIGHT?' 
 
 -'eh, what the hell are you talking about? You know I'm bi...' 
 
'We've been dating for over a month, you obnoxious cow!' 
 
 -'I actually only came here for a cappuccino, and...' 
 
'Get your stupid cappuccino elsewhere, queerbaiting homophobic shitface!' Jenny barked. 
 
 Sophie exited the coffee shop the reverse way she came in, keeping her eye on Jenny, who was kicking the window cleaner around the shop now. 
 
 Mrs. Reed scraped her throat. 
 
 Jenny looked up, her hair sticking out of her ponytail in an electric manner, sweat pearling on her temples.'WHAT' 
 
'I really can not keep you in a job like this, Jenny, you know that. Consider this your last warning. Please go home now and take care of your... temper. See you tomorrow.' 
 
'Fine.' Jenny undid her apron and began to collect her things from behind the counter. As she was about to leave, Mrs. Reed spoke up again. 
 
'Oh, and Jenny?' 
 
'Yes?' 
 
'These glasses are a hoax. I got them from my sister, as a joke. You will notice the letters are too small to actually read.' 
 
 Jenny lifted the glasses up to her eyes, to notice Mrs. Reed was not bullshitting her. Nothing was legible.'yeah..' 
 
'Yeah. Get some sleep.' 
 
 
. 
 
. 
 
 
 ( I'm trying to improve as a writer so I am grateful for constructive feedback at all times! Oh and English is my third language, so by all means, if I've made stupid mistakes using words wrong, please tell me. Thank you! )

With an audible exhalation, Jenny threw down her coffee-stained tea towel, grabbed the glass cleaner and walked around the counter to expiate her shift. Mrs. Reed called over.'Cleaning the stupid display like you said,' she replied in a grumpy mumble.

As Reed turned her back, Jenny got hold of the glasses, turned her back on her supervisor and had a look at the glasses. They were n't sunglasses; they were regular glasses. They looked a bit spacey, hip, but the glass was clear. She polished them with her rag and looked through them.

Funny; she could see fine through them. They did n't look like glasses for half-blind people at all. Half-amused, she put them on and carried on cleaning. original_text:
Let me tell you about my neighbor Jake. 
 
 The neighborhood is a fair distance from town, up where the foothills yield to the mountains. The company where I used to work was sucked into a negative dimension leaving all of us on the brink of oblivion for a torturous 6 months as a result of a botched super-battle. We all received large settlements from the Alliance of Heroes as a result. I invested it, quit the day job, and moved someplace scenic to focus on my dream of sculpting. 
 
 Big plots out here, only a couple houses within sight of my hilltop cabin. One of them of course belongs to Jake. He has a nice Modern style place nestled up against the small mountain that forms the back of our little valley. Friendly guy, the only neighbor that came to greet me and help me during the move in. Said he'd moved there with his wife after he made some money selling his tech startup just out of school. 
 
 No big deal, right? So I settled in, and started to relax. A few weeks later in the middle of the night, I noticed a rumble in the ground. Earthquakes were unheard of in this party of the Rockies so I went to investigate. Made it outside in time to see a giant hole in the mountain behind Jake's place close. Did n't know what to make of it at first. I convinced myself it was a hallucination and almost told my head shrink. 
 
 Good thing I did n't because that's when I noticed that the car traffic leading past my place up to Jake's was odd. The giveaway was the day a semi truck came out without having gone in first. Curiosity got the better of me, screw the authorities I thought. I was going to check this out myself and avoid turning my scenic backyard into a battleground. Catch was I needed an excuse, so I contrived to give them a thank you gift for welcoming me. 
 
 So I welded up one of my smaller works of art and took it over there as a gift. They had a few avant garde pieces out front already, thus I reasoned it was a tasteful offer. Drove right up to the gate and hit the buzzer. Took a while but Jake's lovely wife Clarissa answered and let me in. Nothing seemed out of the ordinary. Polite, neighborly, and effusive over the sculpture I brought. They put it right in the foyer even. 
 
 It was so ordinary that it was suspicious, or maybe that's my paranoia. 6 months of mental agony in the nightmare realm has been known to do that. At any rate they showed me around, and they invited me to stay for dinner. Enjoyed their private art gallery, enjoyed a nice vintage wine over some fresh caught salmon out of the nearby river. A pleasant perfectly ordinary evening. 
 
 Right as I was leaving I asked them not to open the mountain after midnight as it disturbed my pets. I may as well have sprouted a second head based on the looks they gave me. That's when the attack squad materialized and I found myself quickly restrained to a chair. Jake demanded to know why his sleep wave inducer had n't worked on me. To which I informed him I am physically incapable of sleeping anymore ( cause you know: shadow reality exposure ). 
 
 He seemed perplexed by this so I explained my situation, and asked which super category he fell into. Jake was none other than the illustrious Technocrat, Bane of the CyberSquad. He did n't appreciate my quirk about defining oneself in terms of somebody else. Then he thought about it, laughed and gave me the REAL tour of his abode. Super Villains are odd like that. So now he gives me fair warnings about upcoming cataclysms and keeps the minions off my lawn. Throws a great Christmas party though.
rewritten_text:
In a quaint neighborhood nestled amidst rolling foothills and towering mountains, fate intertwined the lives of two extraordinary neighbors, Jake and the narrator. The idyllic setting, far from the bustle of town, provided the perfect backdrop for a blossoming friendship.

The narrator, a skilled sculptor, had recently relocated to this scenic haven, his heart filled with dreams and aspirations. As he unpacked his belongings, he noticed a welcoming presence in the form of Jake, a friendly soul with a modern-style home nestled snugly against the mountain's embrace. From the moment he moved in, Jake extended a helping hand, offering his support and unwavering hospitality.

One fateful night, the tranquil tranquility of the neighborhood was shattered by a tremor that shook the foundations of the earth. The narrator was startled by the rumble and rushed outside to investigate. To his astonishment, he witnessed a colossal chasm carved into the mountain behind Jake's abode. It was as if the earth had conspired to reveal a hidden secret, a testament to the power of nature and the unpredictable twists of fate.

Curiosity consumed the narrator, and he knew he had to uncover the truth. He devised a plan, concocting an excuse to gain entry into Jake's property. With determination etched in his heart, he drove up to the gate and discreetly made his way inside. The aroma of avant-garde art and the vibrant hues of the artwork adorned the space, setting the stage for an unforgettable encounter.

As he presented his gift of art, Jake's eyes lit up with joy and admiration. They exchanged stories, laughed, and forged a bond that would last a lifetime. From that day forward, their friendship blossomed, filled with shared experiences, mutual support, and a deep understanding that only comes from spending time with someone who truly knows you.

Through the ups and downs of life, Jake and the narrator stood by each other. They celebrated each other's successes, offered comfort during times of distress, and always made each other feel valued and loved. Their friendship, rooted in the shared experience of their scenic neighborhood, blossomed into a deep and enduring bond, leaving an indelible mark on their hearts.
rewrite_prompt_og: Rewrite the story with the focus on how the relationship between the two neighbors blossoms into a deep friendship
rewrite_prompt: Rewrite the text to highlight the friendship between the narrator and Jake, focusing on the shared experiences and the scenic neighborhood setting

original_text:
I am not deep enough for my body to collapse under the pressure. Only enough to feel the weight of this water I displace. I can see the sunken debris of the boat. If I look up, I can see the shimmering silhouettes of those I knew floating on the white, sunlit surface. I am too far for light to reach me. I do not know what surrounds me. I do not know what happened to the boat. I do not know how much longer the oxygen in my tank will last. 
 
 
 Here is what I do know: I was vacationing with friends and family in Australia. Some of us wanted to dive in the cages with the sharks. We took the cheapest tour we could. The cages are big enough for only one person. When I went, something happened to the boat, and my cage was detached, sinking to seabed. 
 
 
 I am too deep to be heard. I can not open the cage. I do n't know what's around me. Small thin things, maybe eels, can pass through the bars and slither against the wetsuit, between my legs or against my arms. Larger thinks can push the cage. Earlier, the sharks would rush the cage and bite the bars, then grow bored and leave. But whatever these things are, they do n't do that. The shake and push and shift the cage, then stop for an unspecific, random amount of time that is never brief but never long enough to be comfortable, before they start against. 
 
 
 Breathing is hard. The cage is 1 meter by 2 meters by 3. In this great dark oppressive being of fluidity and weight than has absorbed and encompassed me fully, this ocean, with depth and range that is unfathomable, I am still trapped in a cage. It's large enough to stretch my arms out, or lie down in, if I could, but this only creates the illusion of comfort, and size. I am still trapped, in the crushing unknown, with slick beasts that ca n't be seen that either ignore me and my fate, swimming through the bars I ca n't fit my wrist through, taunting me with their boundless freedom, or they are huge, with the strength and intelligence to grip the bars and push and move the cage, and these creatures are desperate to discover what is stuck inside, away from them. The cage is the only thing protecting me but it also my grave and my coffin, only protecting me to prolong what is to come, waiting me out, subjecting me to the cruelty of callous time, without empathy, for dread to build and oxygen to diminish, as I am forced to confront the greatest, most total, most utter reality there is. 
 
 
 I will die. 
 
 
 Whether I am torn apart, by sharp ivory or unknown arms of something strong and something smart, or whether my life supply is depleted first and I must choke on absence; no matter how it happens, it will happen, and it will happen here. 
 
 
 I will die alone and in pain, in the eternal night of deep sea, where not even star light can ( or, maybe, will ) enter.
rewritten_text:
I'm too deep to be heard and I can't open the cage. It's like being trapped in a giant fish bowl with nothing to do but wait for the sharks to show up. And the worst part? The creatures that live in this underwater world don't even care about me. They just swim around, taunting me with their boundless freedom. It's like being stuck in a cage in the middle of the ocean, surrounded by people who are just laughing at you.

I know, I know, I'm being a bit dramatic. But I'm just trying to lighten the mood. What's the point of being stuck in the middle of nowhere if you can't have a good laugh at yourself?
rewrite_prompt_og: Rewrite with a focus on comedy
rewrite_prompt: Rewrite this text with a more light-hearted and humorous tone

Footsteps? In the middle of the night? It was suspicious indeed, I decide to check it out. I quietly creep down the stairs, and with my cat night- vision eyes, I peer into the living room. 
 My suspicions confirmed, it apparently *was* a burglar. Wearing complete black, he seemed to blend in with the room. The thief seemed to be trying to steal my owner's pride and glory, his most prized possession, the 4K Samsung TV. 
 I know what I must do. I *must* alert my master before it's too late. It is my duty as his guardian. 
 I quickly pounce back upstairs and run into the master bedroom. I hop onto the bed and start meowing as loud as I could. This will surely wake up master. I will save the night! 
 `` Go away you stupid cat'' 
 I hop back down and go back into my Amazon cardboard bed that came with the TV. 
 Oh well, I tried my best.

With swiftness and cunning, I sneak past the unsuspecting homeowner, my feline eyes scanning the surroundings. I am mindful of every sound, every movement, yet I press onward, my determination burning bright. My paws land on the plush carpet, my footsteps echoing through the halls, but the homeowner is oblivious. As I approach the coveted TV, my heart thumps with excitement. The prize is within reach, but I know, my dear feline adversary, a guardian of his master's pride, is not far away. I must outsmart this clever cat and claim my prize, no matter the cost.

original_text:
Darius hits the wall with a loud thump, flung backward by a blast of magic to his chest. Vervain circles his location with caution, a faint smile playing across her lips. He coughs up blood, the red dotting the stone floor in front of him. 
 
 ‚Äú You really thought that just a curse to repel magic would help you? ‚Äù Vervain giggles at the thought, stepping forward. ‚Äú It repels the effect of the magic but never the force. Not that you ‚Äô ll live long enough to see that put into action. ‚Äù 
 
 Her fingers dig into the short hair on his scalp, pulling him up to look her in the face. Darius groans in pain. Vervain ‚Äô s eyes twinkle with delight. 
 
 ‚Äú Did you think you were the Chosen One? The one the masses claim will kill me? ‚Äù 
 
 Unable to take a deep enough breath to respond, Darius only gives another cry of pain. He had the mark, found the sword, even matched the description but has no idea what ‚Äô s gone wrong. He had even invested time in training with the local garrison under the pretense of working for Vervain ‚Äô s army. She should be dead, the sword stuck through her. Instead, the sword couldn ‚Äô t even put a scratch on her. 
 
 ‚Äú I think your head will look lovely on the gate. A reminder for all. ‚Äù Vervain lights up her hand with flames, the orange glow far too close for Darius ‚Äô s comfort. Her grin grows wider by the second. ‚Äú What a pleasure this ‚Äô ll be. It ‚Äô s been far too long since I ‚Äô ve killed an intruder. ‚Äù 
 
 There ‚Äô s a crash through the window, Vervain letting Darius drop to the floor to block a blast of magic with both hands. The stonework wraps around him like a blanket, swallowing him up. He weakly struggles until he ‚Äô s thrown out onto the grass, laying there too weak to move further. 
 
 ‚Äú Come on, get up! ‚Äù It ‚Äô s an older man yelling at him. Darius struggles to even get to his knees. The man gives in, glancing up towards where blasts of magic in a rainbow of colors are being pelted back and forth. ‚Äú Fucking idiot. Where ‚Äô s the sword? ‚Äù 
 
 Darius can only stare at him, focused on the dark scruff across his cheeks. 
 
 ‚Äú For fuck ‚Äô s sake! ‚Äù The man picks Darius up with some effort, throwing him across the saddle of a horse before hopping on. ‚Äú You better hope that Isadora doesn ‚Äô t get hurt for you, because I ‚Äô m going to do worse than Vervain would to you if that ‚Äô s the case! ‚Äù 
 
 The man smacks the reins, sending the horse flying across the grassy, moonlit field. With each stride of the horse, Darius feels more pain run through him. He ‚Äô s more like dead weight for the horseman compared to someone actually trying to stay on. 
 
 He closes his eyes, gritting his teeth against the tears that threaten to come. It wasn ‚Äô t supposed to be like this. 
 
 ***

rewritten_text:
Darius hits the wall with a loud thump, flung backward by a blast of magic to his chest. Vervain circles his location with caution, a faint smile playing across her lips. He coughs up blood, the red dotting the stone floor in front of him.

"You really thought that just a curse to repel magic would help you?" Vervain giggles at the thought, stepping forward. "It repels the effect of the magic but never the force. Not that you'll live long enough to see that put into action."

Her fingers dig into the short hair on his scalp, pulling him up to look her in the face. Darius groans in pain. Vervain's eyes twinkle with delight.

"Did you think you were the Chosen One? The one the masses claim will kill me?"

Unable to take a deep enough breath to respond, Darius only gives another cry of pain. He had the mark, found the sword, even matched the description, but has no idea what's gone wrong. He had even invested time in training with the local garrison under the pretense of working for Vervain's army. She should be dead, the sword stuck through her. Instead, the sword couldn't even put a scratch on her.

"I think your head will look lovely on the gate. A reminder for all." Vervain lights up her hand with flames, the orange glow far too close for Darius's comfort. Her grin grows wider by the second. "What a pleasure this'll be. It's been far too long since I've killed an intruder."

There's a crash through the window. Vervain letting Darius drop to the floor to block a blast of magic with both hands. The stonework wraps around him like a blanket, swallowing him up. He weakly struggles until he's thrown out onto the grass, laying there too weak to move further.

"Come on, get up!" It's an older man yelling at him. Darius struggles to even get to his knees. The man gives in, glancing up towards where blasts of magic in a rainbow of colors are being pelted back and forth. "Fucking idiot. Where's the sword?"

Darius, the Chosen One, turns out to be completely useless. His delusions of grandeur had led him to believe that he was destined for greatness, but in reality, he is just a pawn in Vervain's game.

original_text:
I'm the luckiest one I know. Not the best looking, certainly not the brightest, but I am the luckiest. Because, when we figured it out, that's when they came for us. Dr. Henrique was the first to know. If it was n't for his gadget we'd have all been shit outa luck - pardon my language. See, I do n't even know what to tell you - I'm not even one of the scientists. I'm just one of the janitors who cleaned the floors at the lab on weeknights. But Dr. Henrique, that man was smart. He managed to open some door - or hole he called it. A'worm hole', that's it. It was some crack outside of this world and into - well, he said it was the world around us. One that we ca n't see. Said there was another universe outside of ours, and that they - those things - made us. Apparently they were n't too happy when he found out either. One by one, I watched as everybody started vanishing. First there was a lab assistant, then Josia, the older man that helped me with the floor scrubbing machine. 
 
 I remember Dr. Henrique looked right at me when he saw what was going on. He said, `` Levi, keep your eyes open, do n't blink!'' He was going on and on about how it was something to do with observation and how when you blink they can use your new observation to make some probability wave collapse. I did n't really follow all of it, because, well you know how it is. If somebody says, `` Whatever you do, do n't think about an elephant!''. Well, hell, what's the first damn thing that's gon na pop into your head? An elephant, that's what. It's just human nature. My mama used to say, `` Do n't look now...'' and we'd always look, first thing. It's just how we are made, you know? 
 
 Well, I blinked. Next thing I know, I'm standin' in the middle of a grocery store aisle holding a can or creamed corn. I was so surprised that I blinked again, and damn if it did n't beat everything - sorry about the language again - but now I was on some big ship in the middle of the ocean. I could n't figure out what was going on, then I remembered the Dr saying, `` Do n't blink, do n't blink.'' And so I shut my eyes tight and held my hands over'em. I could still hear the sea gulls flying over head and I could smell something like fish - it was strong. Maybe just cause my sense of smell was stronger now that I could n't use my eyes. I heard some people talking a good distance away, somewhere over to the right of me. Sounded like some fishermen. One of them was angry. 
 
 `` What did I tell you, fool! Are you some kinda ignoramous? I said hold the net like this until I tell you to let it go. Just get! Go sit over there till I holler for you! ``, shouted the fisherman to someone close to him. I still could n't see with my hands cupped over my eyes, but I heard some heavy footsteps headed in my direction. I started to worry because I knew I was n't supposed to be on that boat. And I knew that whoever it was comin' around that corner was gon na know I was n't supposed to be there too. But something about his footsteps sounded strange. There was no confidence in his step. Kinda like he was unsure of his footing. He was sort of shuffling and I could hear him grabbing at the sides of the ships cabin as he got closer. I kept thinkin' if he's not careful, he's gon na run right into... And something collided with me. I managed to keep my hands over my eyes as I stumbled back. `` Oh excuse me, I apologize sir, pardon me. ``, came the voice of the other person. `` You see I have a vision impairment so I ca n't really see where I'm goin''. That voice sounded so familiar. In fact, I knew that I had worked alongside that same voice every weeknight for the last four years. `` Josia? Is that you?'' 
 
 `` How.... how'd you know my name? ``, came the bewildered sound of Josia. `` Nobody here knows my name - or not my real name anyway. Who are you?'' 
 
 `` Josia, it's me Levi! Do n't you even recognize my voice? Have you gone senile?'' 
 
 `` Levi Ellis, it's really you. It's really you! I thought I'd never see anybody again after that accident at the university all those years ago! ``, said Josia. 
 
 `` Years ago? What are you talkin' about Josi? ``, said Levi as he tried to keep from the temptation of taking a peek at his old buddy, `` You had n't been drinkin' the same stuff them sailors have been have you? All that stuff that happened in the lab, that was just about ten minutes ago.'' 
 
 `` Ten minutes? Ten minutes?! ``, Josia seemed lost for words. `` I ca n't keep it all straight. ``, he began again, `` I was bouncin around from place to place. Everything was different. I was underground at one place. On an old oil rig for a minute or two. Then I was standing on a stage holding a microphone. I looked out into the crowd and there had to be thousands out there. A whole football stadium full. I could just kick myself. I wish I had figured it out then.'Just keep your damn eyes shut', I should have said to myself. But I did n't. I blinked. And here I was, on this ship. After that, I decided to try and control it. So I put on this blindfold and convinced everybody that I had lost my vision to some disease, but it was n't contagious as long as I kept them covered with this thick scarf. As long as I was willing to work they did n't ask too many questions. Seem they get stowaways on ships like these from time to time. So Levi, tell me, how did you find me?'' 
 
 `` I did n't find you,'' exclaimed Levi, `` Hell, I would have never even known where to look. I just opened my eyes and wound up here just like you did.'' 
 
 That's when it happened. The first one arrived. Remember when I said something about Dr. Henriques device saving me? Well, back in the lab, we had to wear these little wristbands while we worked. It detected radiation, and if you ever heard it crackle you knew you better get the hell out of dodge. With my hands still over my eyes, I heard a crackle coming from my wrist. 
 
 Josia said, `` Is that... is that what I think it is?'' And with that, he let out the most unnatural, most ungodly scream I have ever heard in my life. 
 
 `` Josi, what is it!? Are you ok? I ca n't see you, I ca n't blink or I'll disappear! What's wrong Josi?!'' 
 
 `` It's got me, the damn thing's got me! ``, Josie shouted, `` Run Levi, run!'' 
 
 Run? Where the hell am I supposed to run? I thought to myself. I'm on a fishing ship out in the middle of the god forsaken ocean. Where am I gon na go? One of those damn creatures had found Josi and come for him, and now it was gon na get me too. Gon na get everybody that knew the truth. Everybody that could blink. That's when I decided to do it. I've got the ability to go anywhere, right in the palm of my hands - I just have to release it. So I dropped my hands and opened my eyes. Opened them up to a new reality. I'll be damned. I was holding a microphone, in front of a crowd of thousands. Except, I was n't singing a song. I was in a suit and had my hand on the holy word. I was about to take an oath - as the first blind and black president of the United States of Pangea. This is for you Josia, this is for you.
rewritten_text:
I'm the luckiest one I know. Not the best looking, certainly not the brightest, but I am the luckiest. Because, when we figured it out, that's when they came for us. Dr. Henrique was the first to know. If it was n't for his gadget we'd have all been shit outa luck - pardon my language. See, I do n't even know what to tell you - I'm not even one of the scientists. I'm just one of the janitors who cleaned the floors at the lab on weeknights. But Dr. Henrique, that man was smart. He managed to open some door - or hole he called it. A'worm hole', that's it. It was some crack outside of this world and into - well, he said it was the world around us. One that we ca n't see. Said there was another universe outside of ours, and that they - those things - made us. Apparently they weren't too happy when he found out either. One by one, I watched as everybody started vanishing. First there was a lab assistant, then Josia, the older man that helped me with the floor scrubbing machine.

I remember Dr. Henrique looked right at me when he saw what was going on. He said, `` Levi, keep your eyes open, do n't blink!'' He was going on and on about how it was something to do with observation and how when you blink they can use your new observation to make some probability wave collapse. I did n't really follow all of it, because, well you know how it is. If somebody says, `` Whatever you do, do n't think about an elephant!''. Well, hell, what's the first damn thing that's gon na pop into your head? An elephant, that's what. It's just human nature. My mama used to say, `` Do n't look now...'' and we'd always look, first thing. It's just how we are made, you know?

Well, I blinked. Next thing I know, I'm standing in the middle of Neverland with Tinkerbell and Peter Pan. I was so surprised that I blinked again, and damn if it didn't beat everything - sorry about the language again - but now I was in the Shire with the hobbits. I could n't figure out what was happening.

original_text:
Her phone buzzed angrily against the wooden table. Her eyes flickered for a second away from the reality TV show, and then after a second, she lazily flicked the screen, taking the call. 
 
 ``'Ello?'' 
 
 `` Oh god. Lily. Thank god. You picked up. Oh god. M-Mom. Dad. They- Oh god.'' 
 
 Her back tightened and she sat up. `` Rose? What's wrong?'' 
 
 `` T-there's blood everywhere. Mom - Dad - they are missing their heads!'' Her voice dissolved into ragged sobs. 
 
 Lily hesitated. She stared for a second at the laughing faces on television before shaking herself back to reality. A breath slowly left her mouth. `` Stop joking. It is n't funny.'' 
 
 `` Why would I joke about this?!'' Rose's voice came out as a shriek. `` Their heads are gone! Oh god!'' 
 
 `` Stay right there. Call the cops. I am coming over.'' Lily quickly quit the call. She stared at the screen before doubling over onto the ground, holding her stomach tight. 
 
 `` Oh god. I ca n't believe this.'' Her shoulders shook. 
 
 The giggles finally spilled out, turning into a cackle. `` Oh god. I almost started laughing! That was too perfect. It's a shame I was n't there to see the dumb look on her cunt face. Oh boo hoo. My loving mommy and daddy are dead!'' 
 
 With a labored effort she pulled herself up, looking for her keys, her back still vibrating with giggles. As the television roared behind her, she glanced reflectively at the ceiling. `` Huh. I wonder if I will make it time to see her stupid face when she finds her boyfriend in the bathroom.''

original_text:
D1138 was ushered into the swamp. He brandished a mop, bucket, and squeegee in nervous hands. 682 was secure, he whispered to himself, it is contained, I am protected. He failed to lose the jitters. The artificial swamp that used to contain the foundation's most dangerous anomaly was entirely too quiet, especially for a swamp. `` No wonder he breaks out every month, he must be bored'' 1138 began mopping the dirt encrusted walkways of the pen. Dirt gave way to blood, gave way to steel. He ambivalently enjoyed the blood waterfall a moment before he lost it from the smell. How long had it been since anyone had cleaned its cage? He pondered and began to squeegee the quadruple paned, security windows. Quietly irked at the minute filth trapped between the individual panes. He prayed for a buffer to get the claw marks out. Struggling against a particular spot of a five-clawed impression he swore as the invisible debris fought his squeegee and tore the brush. Then he froze, was the glass... breathing? He was moving before he could realize why, screaming before he lost squeegee, bucket, and arm with it, `` CONTAINMENT....'' and 682 leapt from the window, tearing across walkway, pressing him against the door, keycard against the lock. The horrid, reptilian monstrosity losing its transparency bounded into the hall. 1138 screaming in agonizing pain beneath the crushing weight as the SCP howled and drooled caustic acid sizzling the steel inched from his face. With a bound, the creature was across the long hallway, bowling over the security personnel attempting to tranquilize it in time. 1138 was blind to the struggle, surrounded by sizzling acid already eating at the ruin of his uniform and his skin. He started to his feet, slipped in the caustic mess, burning himself horribly before tipping his mop bucket in painful, but effective, relief from the beasts venom. He stumbled through the doorway. The roars of the terrible monster far down the hall, red emergency lights flicking on, disguising the mess of bodies 682 left in his wake. `` Fuck this'' he muttered, tripping over legs, arms, feeling the faces of people unfamiliar to him in the cold red light. He walked in a daze, barely able to tell the fight was n't going well. When he turned a corner there would be more bodies, more blood, and open doors that he knew should not be. He found one marked stairs, and nimbly thumbed the latch. It gave open with none of the typical security lag and he knew the building was in trouble. He climbed upwards in a stupor, his body heavy, dragging on the steps. No security lighting in here, no flashlight. He tripped, fell, cried, and started again. He was cold, and he felt watched. He found a corner, waited for the shock to take him. He dozed lightly, until a nearby howl roused him with pumping adrenaline. He took to the stairs two at a time, three if he could manage, upwards into the frigid cold. He collapsed at the landing, panting for breath and feeling the awful cold sear his lungs. ``... youumusstbescaaared'' something hissed behind him and he flipped on his back, screaming. Hallucinations, he swore. There was only the dark before him and around him, then, quite suddenly, inside him. He felt himself freeze inside and he knew then he'd taken the wrong stairway. 
 
 -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- --

rewritten_text:
Once upon a time, in a faraway swamp, there lived a courageous warrior named D1138. One day, he was tasked with guarding the dangerous anomaly, 682, which had been contained within the swamp. With a mop, bucket, and squeegee, D1138 bravely took on the responsibility of keeping the anomaly at bay.

As he began to mop the dirt-laden walkways, D1138 couldn't shake the feeling that the swamp was eerily quiet. He began to wonder if the anomaly was bored and decided to break free. Suddenly, a blood waterfall erupted from the ground, and D1138 found himself immersed in a gruesome scene. The stench of blood and steel filled his senses, and he couldn't help but feel ambivalent about the violence.

After cleaning the blood and squeezing the soiled windows, D1138 prayed for a buffer to remove the claw marks left by the anomaly. As he struggled against the stubborn debris, he swore in frustration and froze, his senses tingling. The glass began to breathe, and he knew that the anomaly was breaking free from its containment.

With a terrifying roar, the anomaly burst out of the window, tearing across the walkway and pressing D1138 against the door. The acidic venom burned his skin and consumed him, but D1138 refused to give up. He stood his ground, his mop bucket serving as a shield against the beast's wrath.

As the anomaly roared and bounded down the hallway, D1138 stumbled through the doorway, his uniform smoldering and his skin burned. He fought his way through the acidic mess, tipped his bucket in relief, and stumbled back to his feet. The battle raged on, and D1138 fought tirelessly to contain the anomaly.

Finally, with a sigh of relief, D1138 watched as the anomaly was subdued and the emergency lights flickered on. The swamp breathed a sigh of relief, and D1138 stood tall, his courage unwavering. And so, the tale of D1138, the warrior who saved the swamp from danger, was passed down through generations.

original_text:
An empty bridge, around 5:45 PM. Dusk, when the light is hardest for the onboard cameras to interpret. It was snowing, too, which adds a second layer of complexity. Light can reflect from ice on the road, or on the bridge. Gusting snow can look like another vehicle to some of the sensors. And the grey snow jacket of an eight year old girl can appear identical to the snow-covered shrubs next to her. 
 
 Her name was Sarah, and she had just started third grade. Her bus stop was across the street right at the front of the bridge, and her mother was running too late to escort her to the stop. Her mother says she always looked both ways before crossing, but of course she remembers her daughter as a perfect angel. Or maybe Sarah did exactly as she was supposed to, and just did n't see or hear the two cars speeding down the street. 
 
 The Toyota evaluated the situation immediately. Infrared scanners captured the little girl's image and predicted her movements before her foot even touched the pavement. Sensors in the wheels evaluated the road conditions and determined that the ice made it impossible to brake in time to prevent an accident. There was a 68 percent chance that applying full brakes at this speed would send the car spinning off the road or over the side of the bridge and into the icy river, killing all three passengers. Programming limitations made that an unacceptable risk. And so,.7 seconds after Sarah stepped into the roadway, a decision was made. 
 
 The car swerved into oncoming traffic. It knew that my car was approaching from the opposite direction. It knew that I was the only passenger. It knew the speed that I was traveling. And it communicated its decision to my car almost instantaneously so that my vehicle could veer away in time to prevent the collision. 
 
 How was the Toyota supposed to know that my car was on manual at the time? 
 
 I heard the `` ding'' as the car requested control again, but by the time I reacted, it was already too late. I saw the shocked faces of the other passengers as the hoods of our cars plowed together and crumpled. They were n't wearing seatbelts; who did these days? My eyes closed, but even over the squelch of twisting metal, I could still hear the sickening thud of the other passengers hitting the pavement. My own car went into a vicious tailspin and slid across the bridge, right into Sarah. She died almost instantly. 
 
 Ironically, I was the only survivor. The only factors that the Toyota had n't been able to predict were my love for manual driving, and my sheer stupidity for doing it in such conditions.
rewritten_text:
"Oh boy, what a jam! It was pitch black out on that bridge, like the devil was playing hide-and-seek with the lights. And the snow was falling like a blizzard, which was messing with all the sensors and stuff. I mean, you could hardly see a thing. It was like trying to spot a ghost in the snow.

The little girl, Sarah, she was all bundled up in her fluffy snow jacket, which looked exactly like the snow-covered shrubs next to her. Her mom was running late, she had forgotten to escort her to the stop, and she was probably thinking, "This is not my day!"

But guess what, fate was playing a cruel hand on her. The Toyota, it was like a super-fast robot, had all the bells and whistles. It had infrared scanners and sensors that could predict her movements before she even touched the pavement. But the ice, it was like a slippery eel, making it impossible to brake in time. There was a chance that if they slammed on the brakes, they would spin off the road or go over the side of the bridge, so they decided to take a chance.

I was on the bridge, minding my own business, when I heard the ``ding'' as the car requested control. By the time I reacted, it was already too late. I saw the Toyota swerving into oncoming traffic, and I knew that I was the only passenger who was going to survive.

So, I guess you could say that I was the hero of the day, rescuing Sarah from certain death. And you know what, I'm going to write a book about it. I'm going to call it "The Snow Queen's Dance" and it's going to be a bestseller.

original_text:
`` Hey boss, we got a problem.'' 
 
 I turn my attention away from Mr. Fluffles and focus on the large, silver haired man across from me. 
 
 `` What kind of problem, Uncle Gino?'' 
 
 `` It's the Marconi family. They've started to move in on our turf. I hear they've even opened up a new restaurant on Sixth Street.'' 
 
 Mr. Fluffles bats at my arm and I turn back to him, reaching down to scratch him behind his ears. He purrs happily. 
 
 `` Oh, Uncle Gino, honestly. It's not that big of a deal. A little friendly competition never hurt anyone.'' 
 
 Gino eyes me reproachfully. He looks like he wants to say something, but he opts to remain silent. Shrugging, I continue. 
 
 `` In fact, we should congratulate the Marconis on the success of their new restaurant. Have Auntie Chris make them some of her special tiramisu and deliver it their Sixth Street location with my compliments.'' 
 
 Gino's eyes widen with understanding. `` Oh, just like the Caprelli family.'' 
 
 I nod my head and shift my scratching fingers down the small of Mr. Fluffle's back. The milk white Persian arcs his back in pleasure. 
 
 `` Yes, just like the Caprellis. It's a real pity about that gas explosion. How is Joe Caprelli anyways?'' 
 
 Uncle Gino smirks. `` Last I heard he was still breathing through a tube.'' 
 
 I shake my head sadly. `` Terrible, just terrible. Please, send some flowers to his hospital room with my regards.'' 
 
 Uncle Gino looks taken aback. I can hear him mumble `` Jesus Christ...'' under his breath. No doubt he is touched by my compassion. 
 
 `` Anything else Gino?'' 
 
 `` No, that's all. I'll get right on that tiramisu and them flowers.'' 
 
 `` Great! Thanks Gino, you're a great help as always.'' 
 
 Gino smiles and steps out of the room. Once the door is closed, I pick Mr. Fluffles up and look at him in his cute little squished face. 
 
 `` Who's a fat little smudge of fluff? Yes you! It's Mr. Fluffles! It is! It is!'' 
 
 -- - 
 
 Gino closes the door behind him, and instantly the tension leaves his body. With a boss like Mike `` The Cat Man'' Rappa, every moment is a tense one. The man's bloodlust was legendary, and being a member of his family did n't necessarily offer any protection. Cousin Tony is waiting for him outside. He's sweating bullets. 
 
 `` How'd it go?'' 
 
 Gino lights a cigarette and smiles in Tony's direction. `` Fine. Boss has decided to direct our more violent efforts outside of the family this time. Get Auntie Chris on the line, tell her to get cooking another one of her bombs ready to send to the new coke house on Sixth. And somebody call Seqoia Jim, Boss wants to wrap things up with Joe Caprelli. Quietly.'' 
 
 Tony looks confused. `` You want Seqoia Jim to wrap up Joe Caprelli. What, like a present?'' 
 
 Gino smacks him on the back of his head. 
 
 `` No dumbass! I want Seqoia Jim to put poison in Caprelli's IV. Ai n't you heard the expression'wrapped up' before? Honestly Tony, sometimes you're a real fucking idiot.''
